channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: @liamputt If the whole nation ends up in the landfill beside our old white washers and dryers, we probably shouldn’t be surprised.

Schools used to teach outlining as a way to plan a piece of writing. I tend to use an outline as the actual place where I do the writing, thinking, and revising.
Not so much for poems, though.

Out by the curb, a city truck with its claw arm just grabbed the washing machine that served this household well since 1994. At the appliance shop, they shook their heads, saying, yes, they used to make them like that. Machines today, they said, are built to last 6-8 years.
How good writing resembles the two-tray balance from old chemistry labs. https://t.co/lCAgOuDSrz
Most social media platforms are pro-talker, anti-writer. https://t.co/TtNT1VKAPa
Not having to know. How this idea has evolved over a few years in this writer's social media posts. https://t.co/TtNT1VKAPa
Writers believe that similar versions of a sentence do not give the same pleasure nor mean the same thing.
Who else but Monty Python could make comedy from a two-tray balance we oldsters recall from chemistry lab days? https://t.co/0Yct3a9g2O https://t.co/HFhLBrVGYt
Who else but Monty Python could make comedy from a two-tray balance we oldsters recall from chemistry lab days? https://t.co/0Yct3a9g2O
@davewiner Possibly some hybrid of Twitter and Wiki might have come into existence--I can't imagine what creativity might follow.
I do not believe that things will turn out well, but the idea that they might is of decisive importance. —Max Horkheimer Via Paul @Holdengraber. https://t.co/U0MNfikTAa

“The real engine at the heart of broken systems, the most insidious, burrowing thing, isn’t their cruelty: It’s the way power obliterates consequences, the certainty that those responsible, by virtue of how deeply the game is rigged in their favor, will always get away with it.” https://t.co/XDbM8bm0tG

This review by @OmarElAkkad begins with a tiny, potent, free-standing essay about how power works. https://t.co/ACJx1zYDO4
The first half of @OmarElAkkad’s miniature essay on power: the incident. https://t.co/WV4gxjtyC9
The second half of @OmarElAkkad’s miniature essay on power: the reflection. https://t.co/WsdPdmEpZs
Why if Pence had handed the election to Trump, there would no longer be a country called Ukraine. https://t.co/ZLmv6jmYPB
Scott Stantis on the Osborne 1. https://t.co/gMC3RQA9hw
Why if Pence had handed the election to Trump, there would be no longer be a country called Ukraine. https://t.co/ZLmv6jmYPB
@davewiner Beyond quick fixes for typos and clarity, I don’t know.
What's the magic number? How many people who write about your topic do you have to read before you're likely to hear about most any new development? https://t.co/7GtamTCnDc

America is like an oldies act, he said, "whose performers no longer speak but play their tired tunes for a paycheck and take separate cabs to the airport – everybody gassed, gassed, gassed." https://t.co/9z7xm97FqE
There’s always someone calculating the benefits of selling out to the invading army. https://t.co/AMRsyHobqe
Today’s Wordl https://t.co/IK8f8oiQ8x

"What an Oscar Win for ‘CODA’ Tells Us About Apple’s Power." https://t.co/6KJmfhpTQH
I don't know enough to quibble with the particulars of this opinion piece, but the "on the other hand" move sometimes waters things down in an op-ed. https://t.co/qeQnn6yoze

item.title: defundFoxNews Hard to tell exactly what Google Alerts scans each day, but no action just yet for this new standing search, to be delivered in a daily email. https://t.co/NBb0Il2XwQ
